item.title: John add a quote by Lawrence Durrell
item.description: "What are stars but points in the body of God where we insert the healing needles of our terror and longing?" -- Lawrence Durrell

item.title: John add a quote by Lawrence Durrell
item.description: "The effective in art is what rapes the emotions of your audience without nourishing its values. " -- Lawrence Durrell

item.title: John add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "The silent bear no witness against themselves." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: John add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "Ironically enough, the only people who can hold up indefinitely under the stress of modern war are psychotics. Individual insanity is immune to the consequences of collective insanity." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: John add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "Industrial man—a sentient reciprocating engine having a fluctuating output, coupled to an iron wheel revolving with uniform velocity. And then we wonder why this should be the golden age of revolution and mental derangement." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: John add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "Facts are ventriloquist’s dummies. Sitting on a wise man’s knee they may be made to utter words of wisdom; elsewhere, they say nothing, or talk nonsense, or indulge in sheer diabolism." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: John add a quote by Aldous Huxley
item.description: "What a gulf between impression and expression! That’s our ironic fate—to have Shakespearean feelings and (unless by some billion-to-one chance we happen to be Shakespeare) to talk about them like automobile salesmen or teen-agers or college professors. We practice alchemy in reverse—touch gold and it turns into lead; touch the pure lyrics of experience, and they turn into the verbal equivalents of tripe and hogwash." -- Aldous Huxley

item.title: John add a quote by Ned Rorem
item.description: "Sooner or later you’ve heard all your best friends have to say. Then comes the tolerance of real love. The same holds true for music. " -- Ned Rorem

item.title: John add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "When a man feels fear without reason, you call him to the attention of a psychiatrist; you are not so careful to protect the meaning, the nature and the dignity of love." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: John add a quote by Ayn Rand
item.description: "Those who tell you that man is unable to perceive a reality undistorted by his senses, mean that they are unwilling to perceive a reality undistorted by their feelings. "Things as they are" are things as perceived by your mind; divorce them from reason and they become "things as perceived by your wishes." -- Ayn Rand

item.title: John add a quote by Albert Camus
item.description: "I cling like a miser to the freedom that disappears as soon as there is an excess of things." -- Albert Camus

item.title: John add a quote by Louis-Ferdinand Celine
item.description: "Poverty is a giant who uses your features like a piece of cotton waste to wipe a filthy world. " -- Louis-Ferdinand Celine

item.title: John add a quote by Stephen Mitchell
item.description: "If good happens, good; if bad happens, good. " -- Stephen Mitchell

item.title: John add a quote by Hermann Hesse
item.description: "What we can and should change is ourselves: our impatience, our egoism (including intellectual egoism), our sense of injury, our lack of love and forbearance. I regard every other attempt to change the world, even if it springs from the best intentions, as futile. " -- Hermann Hesse

item.title: John add a quote by Hermann Hesse
item.description: "To hold our tongues when everyone is gossiping, to smile without hostility at people and institutions, to compensate for the shortage of love in the world with more love in small, private matters; to be more faithful in our work, to show greater patience, to forgo the cheap revenge obtainable from mockery and criticism: all these are things we can do. " -- Hermann Hesse

item.title: John add a quote by Hermann Hesse
item.description: "Sentimentality is a basking in feelings that in reality you don't take seriously enough to make the slightest sacrifice to or ever translate into action. " -- Hermann Hesse

item.title: John add a quote by Hermann Hesse
item.description: "When a writer receives praise or blame, when he arouses sympathy or is ridiculed, when he is loved or rejected, it is not on the strength of his thoughts and dreams as a whole, but only of that infinitesimal part which has been able to make its way through the narrow channel of language and the equally narrow channel of the reader's understanding. " -- Hermann Hesse

item.title: John add a quote by Arthur Schopenhauer
item.description: "Hope is the confusion of the desire for a thing with its probability. " -- Arthur Schopenhauer

item.title: John add a quote by Friedrich Nietzsche
item.description: "Alas, where is there still a sea in which one could drown: thus our lament resounds – across shallow swamps. " -- Friedrich Nietzsche
